title: 109_hr1862
content: The "Drug Free Sports Act" defines the Secretary as the Secretary of Commerce and professional sports associations as specific leagues. Mandatory drug testing for athletes is required under this Act. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates professional sports associations to implement random drug testing for athletes at least once a year without prior notification. The Secretary of Commerce will issue a list of prohibited substances for testing. The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires random drug testing for athletes once a year without prior notification. The Secretary will issue a list of prohibited substances for testing, which are determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency to be prohibited and by the Secretary to be performance-enhancing. Testing will be done by an independent party, and positive tests will result in penalties. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates random drug testing for athletes annually without prior notice. Positive tests in the professional sports association lead to penalties, including suspension for a minimum of 2 years or permanently for repeat offenders, with a loss of pay during the suspension period. The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires random drug testing for athletes in the professional sports association. Suspensions for positive tests include a loss of pay. Athletes have the right to appeal and must do so within 5 days of learning about the positive test. Appeals must be resolved within 30 days, and penalties are stayed pending the appeal process. The Secretary can exempt professional sports associations with existing policies exceeding regulations from drug testing requirements. Noncompliance may result in fines starting at $5,000,000 and increasing daily. The Secretary must report on the effectiveness of regulations every 2 years to Congress. A study will be conducted on college and secondary school athletes' use of performance-enhancing substances. The study will assess the effectiveness of policies and procedures in detecting and preventing the use of performance-enhancing substances by college and secondary school athletes. A report will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The report will evaluate testing policies for detecting performance-enhancing substances in college and secondary school athletes, with recommendations for expanding regulations to athletic associations.
